posts.name: Nolan Barker
posts.cooked:
This season, team 3414 explored a variety of methods in terms of alignment. We settled on one strategy we found worked “well enough”, but in the background, we were developing a new, and much more elegant, solution; unfortunately, we never got to run it before CMP . But we got right back to work after we got the robot back home, and we were (happily) shocked by how well it worked. We continued adding better features to the program, which we dubbed Autopilot. Now, with thorough testing at IRI and during drive practice,  we’re excited to release Autopilot to the public.

Autopilot is a control system for a 2 dimensional field that focuses on simplicity while retaining powerful features .

Autopilot has a couple of different features that may interest teams:

Fast motion. Autopilot employs a hybrid motion profile that maximizes speed at the start of a path, but smoothness in the back end. More specifically, Autopilot will cause the robot to speed up at a constant acceleration, but then align with constant jerk - which means that we come to a very smooth stop.

Fast code. Autopilot is completely stateless, which means that it never tries to plan ahead into the future.

Nonlinear paths. Autopilot offers control over entry angle , which determines the end direction of the robot. This opens the possibilities of the original beeline drive-to-point to a whole new level.

Easy to use. As a result of its stateless nature, Autopilot exposes a very simple API.

Autopilot is one step up from simple “beeline” drive-to-point solutions that travel in a straight line, towards the target. Autopilot offers more features that allow for more control of the robot’s motion while still obeying the core values of “ simple yet powerful ”.

Inspired by the autonomous strategies of teams like 2056 and 2910, Autopilot maintains a few core aspects of the simple beeline controller:

Stateless design . Autopilot is completely stateless, and doesn’t generate any paths or trajectories. Like a well-tuned PID controller, Autopilot works off of clever design - given some state and a goal, an output can be constructed. Following this output will always drive the current state towards the goal - even though no actual “path” is planned. This means Autopilot “flights” are very inexpensive to calculate on-the-fly.

Stateless design . Autopilot is completely stateless, and doesn’t generate any paths or trajectories. Like a well-tuned PID controller, Autopilot works off of clever design - given some state and a goal, an output can be constructed. Following this output will always drive the current state towards the goal - even though no actual “path” is planned. This means Autopilot “flights” are very inexpensive to calculate on-the-fly.

No hassle . Besides configuring maximum speed, acceleration, and jerk, Autopilot has very little actual configuration necessary. Define your motion constraints, desired behavior, and your target, and.. you’re done.

No hassle . Besides configuring maximum speed, acceleration, and jerk, Autopilot has very little actual configuration necessary. Define your motion constraints, desired behavior, and your target, and.. you’re done.

No plan for the future . By not attempting to “think ahead”, Autopilot doesn’t perform any computation that isn’t necessary right now .

No plan for the future . By not attempting to “think ahead”, Autopilot doesn’t perform any computation that isn’t necessary right now .

Autopilot is not a drop-in replacement for tools like PathPlanner or Choreo. It aims to solve the same problem of autonomous robot navigation, but it does so in a different manner that isn’t suitable for every single use case. Unlike those tools, Autopilot doesn’t try to follow a pre-generated trajectory. The benefits of this have already been described, but this comes at a cost. You cannot modify a path, even if you know the initial and final state. What I mean by this is that you cannot open a GUI and modify the shape of the path. If you really need to fine-tune your paths, Autopilot is not the solution for you. However, is this really necessary? Highly successful teams like 2056 and 2910 both ran relatively simple “drive-to-point” straight-line controls this year, and 2056 boasted what I think is the most dominant auto on the planet. Autopilot only builds onto this simple base, adding more control over the end behavior of the path - as well as providing a smoother end motion profile.

autopilot-path 800×800 14.1 KB

autopilot-path 800×800 14.1 KB

autopilot-path 800×800 14.1 KB

The above graph shows two different paths that the robot can take. Autopilot is capable of behaving in either manner, but the difference is in entry angle . When entry angle is not respected or demanded (the black dashed line), the robot should directly travel towards the target position. However, if the robot needs not only to approach the target, but also do so from a known direction, a second action is taken (the solid purple line). This is the trajectory that Autopilot gravitates towards when respecting entry angle.

You can try to experiment with Autopilot with this Desmos graph and see how Autopilot behaves. Click and drag the purple dot to change starting position, and see the trajectories generated.

Note that Autopilot doesn’t actually generate these trajectories, it only calculates the current velocities required to follow that trajectory. For a more detailed, math-focused description of how Autopilot works, read this page of the Autopilot docs.

Team 3414 ran this version of Autopilot at IRI 2025, and although we had our fair share of other struggles, we didn’t need to make any modifications to our code for alignment. We saw great results. Tracking was smooth, consistent, and we only missed two coral in auto during the event (and we had the vision issue fixed after the third match (2nd miss), after which we proceeded to have 100% coral consistency throughout the rest of our autons. For the remainder of the event, we saw high consistency in alignment in teleop as well. But the best part about Autopilot vs our older solution of just a profiled PID controller (trapezoid profile) was the end behavior. Where the older solution occasionally struggled in the last part of the path, where slowing down is crucial, Autopilot’s smoother end profile gave us faster alignment speeds because we ensured we came to a smooth stop and didn’t overshoot the target.

Example match: IRI Match 86 . We’re top right on red (3414).

In our off-season development of gamepiece tracking, Autopilot is being used again. Because it’s completely stateless, it’s easy to quickly navigate towards a target on the fly - even if the target is moving. We just use the estimated pose of the gamepiece on the field to navigate towards the target.

Thanks for reading! If this sounds like it may be of interest to you or your team, consider giving Autopilot a try! Also feel free to ask questions about Autopilot that I may not have covered!

To see the code, view Autopilot’s Github . Currently, this project is Java-only.

For more information about installation, code use, and the technicalities of Autopilot, read the documentation .

link_counts.title: GitHub - therekrab/autopilot: A simple but powerful solution for autonomous navigation with a holonomic drivetrain.

posts.name: Aidan
posts.cooked: This looks really cool! We use PathPlanner’s On The Fly Generation, but I think this would be more accurate.

posts.name: Yishai Levy
posts.cooked: Assuming I understand rotationRadius correctly, AP will always make the robot spin as fast as possible to the target angle (when in the rotation radius, if one is set)?

posts.name: Ethan Grieshop
posts.cooked: Do you have any gifs of target paths or isolated robot videos of this in action? I think that would make it easier to see the advantages over a traditional solution.

posts.name: Nolan Barker
posts.cooked:
Well, that’s up to you. Autopilot returns a goal heading - you can rotate however fast you’d like to get there. It doesn’t return a rotational speed - only a setpoint.

The reason for this is because Autopilot is mainly about the translation bit of the path, so it leaves the rotation bit up to the user. If it was included, it would just be an internal profiled PID controller which the user would have to supply anyways, so best leave it out.

But if you’re asking if the setpoint is just the target, yeah. I’ve considered adding a rotation interpolation or whatever, but I don’t know if that’s super helpful (but let me know if you think it would be).

posts.name: Nolan Barker
posts.cooked: There’s the Desmos graph I linked in the first post which shows the paths that Autopilot follows, but the majority of the advantages are on the software side - it’s inexpensive to calculate on the fly, and is (so far) easy to work with and control. I don’t have videos of just the robot right now, but I can come back later and post some logs if that’s what you’re looking for.

posts.name: Yishai Levy
posts.cooked:
therekrab:

If it was included, it would just be an internal profiled PID controller which the user would have to supply anyways, so best leave it out.

I wouldn’t necessarily agree. This would affect how the path is followed. Since the path is not pre determined, this might make less of an impact, but the more you rotate the less you can drive forward (which affects the constraints).

posts.name: Nolan Barker
posts.cooked:
Although your max speed is decreased by rotating, this doesn’t affect the shape of the path the robot takes - if I’m understanding what you’re talking about. I don’t know how it works with other swerve controllers, but CTRE ’s FieldCentricFacingAngle request allows the user to specify the speed in the x and y direction as well as specifying an angle to rotate towards as well. These are all respected, if possible, but the robot’s motion will slow down as it rotates. However, the shape of the path should be unaffected. The direction the robot travels in won’t change - although it will have to slow down to follow it and turn.

levyishai:

which affects the constraints

Not really. The constraints represent the maximum velocity, acceleration, and jerk that Autopilot will demand. They’re unaffected if the robot actually can reach them. Let me know if this reply doesn’t make much sense, though - I was a little confused at first by your reply.
This looks interesting. We came to some of the same conclusions on last mile alignment. Going to give this a good read

posts.name: Nolan Barker
posts.cooked:
LPryor:

last mile alignment

Forgive me, but what does this refer to? I haven’t heard this term before.

Sorry my Amazon past is showing. In package delivery a parcel will change hands, with the “last mile”’or the final delivery being the most complex and important.

I refer to last mile in this context because we use path planner to get the robot close to the reef, the for the “last mile” there’s a PID adjustment, and final approach to the reef using TOF sensors:

Your solution is more generalized, but we’re basically doing something very similar

posts.name: joemost
posts.cooked:
therekrab:

Autopilot will cause the robot to speed up at a constant acceleration, but then align with constant jerk - which means that we come to a very smooth stop

This looks very cool. Excited to try this out in the fall.

We used a “DriveToPose” pretty well this year throughout Auto and Teleop to lineup to nodes. It was just profiled pid controllers on each of the dimensions and rotation.

From watching our videos, it isn’t bad but we seem to come to a sudden stop in some cases. Excited to try this out to smooth that out.

posts.name: Dan Peled
posts.cooked:
This seems like an interesting library, as for C++ support which was noted that doesn’t currently exit, I made a rewrite of the library in C++, will add an example likely soon I made sure to copy most of the doc comments and code the same while keeping to follow the C++ conventions.

posts.name: joemost
posts.cooked:
It looks like you ran a similar auto here on your old trapezoidal system? (Correct me if I’m wrong?) https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JZ-BU8fhtIc

It’d be cool to see the difference in your paths plotted vs that sleek auto linked above.

Very excited about this solution and antsi to get my software students to test this. It’ll just be a while haha. I guess we could sim it and likely see a difference. We had some moments where we ‘stomped’ on the brakes.

posts.name: Nolan Barker
posts.cooked:
Yup, that’s exactly what we were running. We ran it at a comparable speed, however the end behavior was simply too jerky, and we missed because of this. (Really, we ran it faster but we missed more so it was effectively slower.) The other main reason that these autos missed so much was because we hadn’t yet introduced any sort of demand for entry angle. Therefore, when we overshot (which was often), we did so in an unpredictable direction. We could be coming in “sideways” to the target with respect to the reef, so instead of stopping at the branch, we’d go too far to the left/right.

However, with Autopilot, we can ensure that our end direction of motion is always towards the reef, which means that if we overshoot (which isn’t even really a problem anymore), we only push into the reef, which is much more tolerant of error because we’re still lined up with the branch.

joemost:

It’d be cool to see the difference in your paths plotted vs that sleek auto linked above.

The old solution utilized PathPlanner for most of the motion, but then used a simple beeline controller (drives straight towards target) with a trapezoidal profile to do the final alignment. Here’s a screenshot of what the path looked like in PathPlanner:

left3 878×403 45.8 KB

left3 878×403 45.8 KB

left3 878×403 45.8 KB

The parts where it’s close to the reef or HP station are where we would switch to a simple beeline controller.

posts.name: Nolan Barker
posts.cooked:
Dan1:

I made a rewrite of the library in C++

Awesome! The library is really very simple (as I’m sure you noticed - really just 4 files) so I figured it would be relatively quick to port - I just don’t have the time to learn C++. I’ll  put a link to it in the docs where the warning is to let users know there’s a C++ option now. In the future, I think it would be possible to merge your project into the “official” repo but I don’t know how that would work with jitpack (which is only for Java). I really appreciate you taking the time to do this!

Update: the link is now on the website’s home page. Thanks a ton!

posts.name: Nolan Barker
posts.cooked:
Update: I’ve downloaded the robot logs from our last match at IRI (quals 86, video linked in first post): logs .

There’s a field called Drivetrain/Velocity which is the drivetrain’s… velocity. In auto, we only use Autopilot so everything you see there is Autopilot at the wheel. Let me know if there’s anything that either doesn’t make sense or seems funny, and I’ll do my best to describe what’s going on.

Here’s the graph for a single alignment:

image 2288×1092 78 KB

image 2288×1092 78 KB

image 2288×1092 78 KB

If you want a more idealized approach that’s just Autopilot (without the noise from sensors and vision), here’s the velocity graph for alignment during simulation: image 2288×1092 74.6 KB As you can see, there’s a slight curve downwards (the “slightness” of this curve can be customized by changing the constraint’s jerk). The robot stops once we’re within tolerance, but you can see how the robot decelerates slower as we approach the target. Mathematically, the robot is told to follow a curve similar to y=x^2 (but scaled).

image 2288×1092 74.6 KB

image 2288×1092 74.6 KB

posts.name: joemost
posts.cooked: Looks really nice. Well Done!!

posts.name: Jeffrey Davis
posts.cooked:
therekrab:

Autopilot will cause the robot to speed up at a constant acceleration, but then align with constant jerk - which means that we come to a very smooth stop.

Why is constant jerk better than constant acceleration here? Is the F=ma too theoretical on the forces the robot experiences? What does the decreasing force do for the smoothness? Is it actually for a faster initial braking and only letting off when you get really close?

Ive done a little digging and there’s some pages that say constant jerk is good in robotics but not really why. I am wondering if you can explain it from your experience here.
